author: Mike Walters
title: Crystal Palace 2-1 Bolton: Benteke brace hands Eagles FA Cup fourth round clash with Manchester City
text:
Christian aid: Benteke bailed Palace out (Photo: Ian Walton) Share Get football   Thank you for subscribing!   
Christian Benteke charged off the bench to hand Sam Allardyce his first win since his 67-day reign as England manager. 
Until Benteke threw off his cape as part of a triple substitution with 28 minutes left, Big Sam was heading for ignominy, and a deepening crisis at Selhurst Park, against his old club. 
But the £27 million Belgian striker’s two goals in nine minutes broke brave, bristling Bolton’s resistance to earn last season’s beaten finalists a home date with Manchester City in the fourth round. 
Benteke rose to head the equaliser from Mathieu Flamini’s cross within six minutes of peeling off his tracksuit before he spun in the box to fire home Andros Townsend’s cut-back. Big Sam was facing his former side (Photo: Bryn Lennon) 
In his programme notes, Allardyce had bemoaned the state of the empire he built at the Macron, saying: “I had mixed feelings going back up to Bolton as it is sad to see the club in the position it is in. 
“The memories of the great days and the excellent team we had when I was manager will always be with me, but to see the stadium less than half-full with stands shut down and the club struggling financially saddened me.” 
No disrespect, Big Sam, but it wasn’t exactly full to bursting in the People’s Republic of Croydon last night. 
And as for struggling financially, does the term ‘balance sheet’ ring any bells? Because your wage bill at Bolton wasn’t a recipe for solvency, was it? 
Seven changes or not, Palace were still able to field seven full ­internationals, and even in an ­atmosphere somewhere between echo chamber and cemetery, they struggled to raise a gallop. 
In an opening cagier than a zoo, Palace enjoyed most of the territory but the clearer chances fell to the Trotters. James Henry put the League One side ahead (Photo: Ian Walton) 
Josh Vela’s fierce shot drifted just wide of the sprawling Julian Speroni’s left-hand post after 11 minutes, and David Wheater hooked over the top from 12 yards after a half-cleared corner. 
But nobody banks on set-pieces more than Big Sam, and Palace were twice close to puncturing the tedium around the half-hour. 
Sullay Kaikai’s wicked free-kick was barely a coat of paint away, then Joe Ledley found the net from Andros Townsend’s corner, only to be booked by referee Stuart Attwell – ­presumably for handball. 
By the time Townsend stood up a cross for Martin Kelly at the far post, and Bolton keeper Ben Alnwick clung on for dear life right on his line, Palace were turning the screw. Benteke scored his first on 68 minutes (Photo: Ian Walton) 
But the five previous meetings between these teams had produced only three goals, and those expecting a classic were lonely optimists. 
Three minutes after the break, however, unchanged Bolton – who suffered a shock home defeat by League One strugglers Swindon on Saturday – shocked their old manager. 
Jay Spearing’s cross was knocked down by Gary Madine and James Henry’s speculative left-foot shot from the edge of the box curled over Speroni and dipped into the corner.
